facts.text: Appellants instituted suit in Court of Subordinate Judge, Monghyr, for recovery of possession of 12 acres 51 cents of land in mauza Bardih, of which defendants Nos. 12 and 13 (second party) are proprietors.
On 12th April 1943, plaintiffs (appellants) admitted by second party as occupancy tenants on payment of Rs. 1,950 as salami and put into possession.
Thereafter, first party (defendants Nos. 1 to 11) trespassed and carried away the crops.
Suit valued at Rs. 2,950 (Rs. 1,950 for possession + Rs. 1,000 past mesne profits).
Defendants Nos. 1 to 11 pleaded possession as tenants on batai system from fasli 1336, acquired occupancy rights; second party had no right to settle with plaintiffs.

Receipts Exhibits A to A-114 (handwriting of patwaris of second party, fasli 1336 to 1347) relied on by trial court to hold defendants 1-11 had possession over 12 years as cultivating tenants and acquired occupancy rights.
Subordinate Judge dismissed suit on 27th November 1945.
Appeal to 1st Additional District Judge, Monghyr (S.J. Title Appeal No. I of 1946), dismissed agreeing receipts genuine and occupancy rights acquired.
Second appeal to High Court Patna (S.A. No. 1152 of 1946); Stamp Reporter objected to valuation, court determined correct valuation Rs. 9,980; additional court-fees paid.
High Court (Sinha and Rai JJ.) held appeal to District Court competent per Ramdeo Singh v. Raj Narain, no prejudice shown, dismissed second appeal.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave granted 29th October 1951.

legal_issues.text: Construction of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act: whether decree by court lacking jurisdiction due to under-valuation is nullity, or can be upheld absent prejudice on merits.
Whether mere change in forum of appeal due to under-valuation constitutes prejudice under section 11.
What constitutes prejudice under section 11, and whether second appeal court must re-examine facts to determine it.

petitioner_arguments.text: District Court lacked competence on true valuation (Rs. 9,980), its decree nullity; High Court should hear as first appeal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: General principles on jurisdiction; Rajlakshmi Dasee v. Katyayani Dasee; Shidappa Venkatrao v. Rachappa Subrao

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternatively, prejudice under s.11 Suits Valuation Act as appeal heard by inferior court (District Court) instead of High Court.
Second appeal court must examine merits/facts to find prejudice, effectively as first appeal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 11 Suits Valuation Act; Section 103 CPC; Ramdeo Singh v. Raj Narain

respondent_arguments.text: Defendants 1-11 in possession as batai tenants from fasli 1336, acquired occupancy rights per receipts A-A114.
No objection to jurisdiction raised earlier; follow Ramdeo Singh v. Raj Narain.

court_reasoning.text: Fundamental principle: decree without jurisdiction is nullity, but s.11 Suits Valuation Act modifies this for over/under-valuation cases; objection only per s.11, not nullity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.11 protects decrees on merits absent prejudice from valuation error; akin to CPC s.21,99.

court_reasoning.text: Cited cases (Rajlakshmi, Shidappa) distinguished: not on s.11; mere change of forum not prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prejudice not mere forum change; Full Benches (Kelu Achan, etc.) correct.

court_reasoning.text: Prejudice under s.11 not error in fact findings or full re-hearing; second appeal can't re-examine facts unless s.100/103 CPC conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prejudice: e.g., improper hearing, summary procedure loss; equitable/revisional jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice here: appellants chose valuation, no objection by parties earlier, full hearing by District Court on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Party can't complain of prejudice from own act.

holdings.text: Decree by court lacking jurisdiction solely due to under-valuation not nullity under s.11 Suits Valuation Act.
Mere change of appellate forum not prejudice under s.11.
Prejudice under s.11 requires failure of justice directly from valuation error, not mere fact errors; second appeal court no power to re-hear facts.
No prejudice to appellants; High Court correctly dismissed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal to District Court competent despite valuation; no prejudice reverses only on merits prejudice.
Decree nullity for stranger in collateral proceeding; s.11 not considered.
Affirmed by Privy Council; not on over/under-valuation or s.11.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rachappa Subrao Jadhav v. Shidappa Venkatrao Jadhav
precedents_cited.relevance: Technical jurisdiction objections not entertained if not raised early; Court Fees Act not weapon.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kelu Achan v. Cheriya Parvathi Nethiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Mere change of forum not prejudice under s.11.
Mere change of forum not prejudice under s.11.

statutes_cited.name: Suits Valuation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs objections to jurisdiction from over/under-valuation; decree not nullity absent prejudice on merits.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: S.99/578/21 policy against reversing on technical jurisdiction absent failure of justice; s.100/103 limit second appeal fact review.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act, the District Court's decree is not a nullity due to under-valuation, mere change of forum is not prejudice, no prejudice on merits shown, and appellants suffered no failure of justice.

key_quotes.text: It is a fundamental principle well established that a decree passed by a Court without jurisdiction is a nullity...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States general rule modified by s.11 Suits Valuation Act.

key_quotes.text: The policy underlying sections 21 and 99 of the Civil Procedure Code and section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is the same, namely, that when a case had been tried by a Court on the merits and judgment rendered, it should not be liable to be reversed purely on technical grounds, unless it had resulted in failure of justice...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legislative policy protecting merits decisions.

key_quotes.text: Prejudice can be a ground for relief only when it is due to the action of another party and not when it results from one's own act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Appellants estopped from complaining of own valuation choice.
